turns.speaker: PARSONS
turns.text: Today's party's finished their sweep, the relief team's out there now. Everybody else is either asleep or running shift in the auto-shop.

turns.speaker: KAMEN
turns.text: You should hit the sack, too.

turns.speaker: PARSONS
turns.text: Nah, I'll stick it out for another hour or so.

turns.speaker: KAMEN
turns.text: What time's sundown?

turns.speaker: PARSONS
turns.text: 'Bout five minutes.

turns.speaker: KAMEN
turns.text: Give me a yell is something happens.

turns.speaker: PARSONS
turns.text: You got it, cowboy.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Hello, there. Who are you?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Miss Harrington's resting, Mr. deWitt. She asked me to see who it is...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: We won't disturb her rest. It seems she left her award in the taxicab. Will you give it to her?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: How do you know my name?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: It's a very famous name, Mr. deWitt.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: And what is your name?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: Phoebe.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Phoebe?

turns.speaker: GIRL
turns.text: I call myself Phoebe.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Why not? Tell me, Phoebe, do you want some day to have an award like that of your own?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: May I come in?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Certainly, Mr. deWitt...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I expected to find this little room overcrowded, with a theater full of people at your feet...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I consider myself lucky they didn't throw things.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Of course your performance was no surprise to me. After the other day I regarded it as no more than - a promised fulfilled.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You're more than kind. But it's still Miss Channing's performance. I'm just a carbon copy you read when you can't find the original...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: You're more than modest.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: It's not modesty. I just don't try to kid myself.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: A revolutionary approach to the Theater. However, if I may a suggestion...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Please do.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I think the time has come for you to shed some of your humility. It is just as false not to blow your horn at all as it is to blow it too loudly...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I don't think I've done anything to sound off about.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: We all come into this world with our little egos equipped with individual horns. If we don't blow them - who will?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Even so. One isolated pretty good performance by an understudy. It'll be forgotten tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: It needn't be.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Even if I wanted to - as you say - be less humble, blow my own horn... how would I do it? I'm less than nobody.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I am somebody.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: After you change, if you're not busy elsewhere, we can have supper.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'd love to! Or should I pretend I'm busy?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Let's have a minimum of pretending. I'll want to do a column about you-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'm not enough for a paragraph.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: - perhaps more than one. There's so much I want to know. I've heard your story in bits and pieces... your home in Wisconsin, your tragic marriage, your financial attachment to Margo - it started in San Francisco, didn't it?  I say - your idolatry of Margo started in San Francisco, didn't it?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: That's right.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: San Francisco. An oasis of civilization in the California desert. Tell me, do you share my high opinion of San Francisco?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Yes. I do.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: And that memorable night when Margo first dazzled you from the stage - which theater was it in San Francisco? Was it - the Shubert?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Yes. The Shubert.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: A fine old theater, the Shubert. Full of tradition, untouched by the earthquake - so sorry - fire... by the way, what was your husband's name?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Eddie...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Eddie what?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'm about to go into the shower, I won't be able to hear you...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I can wait. Where would you like to go? We'll make this a special night...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You take charge.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I believe I will.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Hungry?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Just some coffee.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I'm not surprised. After all that humble pie...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Nothing of the kind. Karen and I had a nice talk.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Heart to heart? Woman to woman? Including a casual reference to the part of "Cora" - and your hopes of playing it.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I discussed it very openly. I told her that I had spoken to Lloyd - and that he was interested.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: She mentioned, of course, that Margo expects to play the part?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Oddly enough - she didn't say a word about Margo. Just that she'll be happy to do what she can to see that I play the part.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Just like that, eh?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Just like that.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Do you know, Eve - sometimes I think you keep things from me.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I don't think that's funny.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: It wasn't meant to be.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I confide in you and rely on you more than anyone I've ever known! To say a thing like that now - without any reason - when I need you more than ever...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I hope you mean what you say, Eve. I intend to hold you to it.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: What a day - what a heavenly day...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: D-day.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Just like it.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: And tomorrow morning you will have won your beachhead on the shores of Immortality...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Stop rehearsing your column... Isn't it strange, Addison? I thought I'd be panic-stricken, want to run away or something. Instead, I can't wait for tonight to come. To come and go...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Are you that sure of tomorrow?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Aren't you?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Frankly - yes.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: It'll be a night to remember. It'll bring to me everything I've ever wanted. The end of an old road - and the beginning of a new one...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: All paved with diamonds and gold?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You know me better than that.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Paved with what, then?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Stars.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: What time?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Almost four.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Plenty of time for a nice long nap - we rehearsed most of last night...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: You could sleep, too, couldn't you?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: The mark of a true killer.  Sleep tight, rest easy - and come out fighting...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Why'd call me a killer?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Did I say killer? I meant champion. I get my boxing terms mixed.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Suites are for expense accounts. Aren't you being extravagant?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Max is paying for it. He and Lloyd had a terrific row but Lloyd insisted... well. Can I fix you a drink?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Also with the reluctant compliments of Max Fabian.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Lloyd. I never have any, and he likes a couple of drinks after we finish - so he sent it up...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Some plain soda.  Lloyd must be expecting a record run in New Haven...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: That's for tonight. You're invited. We're having everyone up after the performance.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: We're?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Lloyd and I.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Addison...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: She's always been so fantastically devoted to Lloyd. I would imagine that only death or destruction could keep her-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Addison, just a few minutes ago. When I told you this would be a night to remember - that it would bring me everything I wanted-

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: - something about an old road ending and a new one starting - paved with stars...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I didn't mean just the Theater.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: What else?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: So that's it. Lloyd. Still just the Theater, after all...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: It's nothing of the kind! Lloyd loves me, I love him!

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I know nothing about Lloyd and his loves - I leave those to Louisa May Alcott. But I do know you.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'm in love with Lloyd!

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Lloyd Richards is commercially the most successful playwright in America-

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You have no right to say such things!

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: - and artistically, the most promising! Eve dear, this is Addison.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Addison, won't it be just perfect? Lloyd and I - there's no telling how far we can go... he'll write great plays for me, I'll make them be great!  You're the only one I've told, the only one that knows except Lloyd and me...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: ... and Karen.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: She doesn't know.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I see. And when was this unholy alliance joined?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: We decided the night before last, before we came up here...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Was the setting properly romantic - the lights on dimmers, gypsy violins off stage?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: The setting wasn't romantic, but Lloyd was. He woke me up at three in the morning, banging on my door - he couldn't sleep, he told me - he's left Karen, he couldn't go on with the play or anything else until I promised to marry him... we sat and talked until it was light. He never went home...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: You sat and talked until it was light...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: We sat and talked, Addison. I want a run of the play contract.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: There never was, there'll never be another like you.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well, say something - anything! Congratulations, skol - good work, Eve!

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: What do you take me for?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I don't know what I take you for anything...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: It is possible - even conceivable - that you've confused me with that gang of backward children you've been playing tricks on - that you have the same contempt for me that you have for them?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'm sure you mean something by that, Addison, but I don't know what...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Look closely, Eve, it's time you did. I am Addison deWitt. I'm nobody's fool. Least of all - yours.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I never intended you to be.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Yes, you did. You still do.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I still don't know what you're getting at. Right now I want to take my nap. It's important that I-

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: - it's important right now that we talk. Killer to killer.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Champion to champion.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Not with me, you're no champion. You're stepping way up in class.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Addison, will you please say what you have to say plainly and distinctly - and then get out so I can take my nap!

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Very well, plainly and distinctly. Although I consider it unnecessary - because you know as well as I, what I am about to say.  Lloyd may leave Karen, but he will not leave Karen for you.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: What do you mean by that?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: More plainly and more distinctly? I Have not come to New Haven to see the play, discuss your dreams, or to pull the ivy from the walls of Yale! I have come to tell you that you will not marry Lloyd - or anyone else - because I will not permit it.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: What have you got to do with it?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Everything. Because after tonight, you will belong to me.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I can't believe my ears...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: A dull cliche.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Belong - to you? That sound medieval - something out of an old melodrama...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: So does the history of the world for the past twenty years. I don't enjoy putting it as bluntly as this, frankly I had hoped that you would, somehow, have known - have taken it for granted that you and I...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... taken it for granted? That you and I...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: You're too short for that gesture. Besides, it went out with Mrs. Fiske.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Then if you won't get out, I'll have you thrown out.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Your name is not Eve Harrington. It is Gertrude Slescynski.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: What of it?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: It is true that your parents were poor. They still are. And they would like to know how you are - and where. They haven't heard from you for three years...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: What of it?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: A matter of opinion. Granted. It is also true that you worked in a brewery. But life in the brewery was apparently not as dull as you pictured it. As a matter of fact, it got less and less dull - until you boss's wife had your boss followed by detectives!

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: She never proved anything, not a thing!

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: But the $500 you got to get out of town brought you straight to New York - didn't it?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: She was a liar, she was a liar!

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Answer my question! Weren't you paid to get out of town?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I had to get in, to meet Margo! I had to say something, be somebody, make her like me!

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: She did like you, she helped and trusted you! You paid her back by trying to take Bill away!

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: That's not true!

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I was there, I saw you and heard you through the dressing room door!

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: You used my name and my column to blackmail Karen into getting you the part of "Cora" - and you lied to me about it!

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: No-no-no...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I had lunch with Karen not three hours ago. As always with women who want to find out things, she told more than she learned...  ... do you want to change your story about Lloyd beating at your door the other night?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Then say so.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Yes, Addison.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: And you realize - you agree how completely you belong to me?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Yes, Addison.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Take your nap, now. And good luck for tonight.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I won't play tonight.  I couldn't. Not possibly. I couldn't go on...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Couldn't go on? You'll give the performance of your life.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I don't suppose there's a drink left...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: You can have one at Max's.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I don't think I'm going.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Because I don't want to.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Max has gone to a great deal of trouble, it's going to be an elaborate party, and it's for you.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: No, it's not.  It's for this.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: It's the same thing, isn't it?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Exactly.  Here. Take it to the party instead of me.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: You're being childish.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'm tired. I want to go home.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Very well. I shall drop you and go on to the party. I have no intention of missing it...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Every now and then, some elder statesman of the Theater or cinema assures the public that actors and actresses are just plain folk. Ignoring the fact that their greatest attraction to the public is their complete lack of resemblance to normal human beings.

turns.speaker: MISS CASWELL
turns.text: Now there's something a girl could make sacrifices for.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: That isn't a waiter, my dear. That's a butler.

turns.speaker: MISS CASWELL
turns.text: Well, I can't yell "Oh, butler," can I? Maybe somebody's name is Butler...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: You have a point. An idiotic one, but a point.

turns.speaker: MISS CASWELL
turns.text: I don't want to make trouble. All I want is a drink.

turns.speaker: MISS CASWELL
turns.text: Let's go sit by the piano.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: You have me confused with Dan Dailey. You go sit by the piano.  And you come sit by me.  Good night.

turns.speaker: MISS CASWELL
turns.text: We never met. That's why.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Miss Caswell is an actress. A graduate of Copacabana School of Dramatic Arts.  Ah... Eve.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: This must be, at long last, our formal introduction. Until now we have met only in passing...

turns.speaker: MISS CASWELL
turns.text: That's how you met me. In passing.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Claudia dear, come closer.  This is Max Fabian. He is a producer. Go do yourself some good.

turns.speaker: MISS CASWELL
turns.text: Why do they always look like unhappy rabbits?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Because that is what they are. Go make him happy.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Feeling better, my dear?

turns.speaker: MISS CASWELL
turns.text: Like I just swam the English Channel. Now what?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: You next move, it seems to me, should be toward television.

turns.speaker: MISS CASWELL
turns.text: Tell me this. Do they have auditions for television?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: That's all television is, my dear. Nothing but auditions.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: It is senseless to insist that theatrical folk in New York, Hollywood and London are no different from the good people of Des Moines, Chillicothe and Liverpool. By and large, we are concentrated gatherings of neurotics, egomaniacs, emotional misfits, and precocious children-

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Gable. Why a feller like that don't come East to do a play...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Answer me this. What makes a man become a producer?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: What makes a man walk into a lion cage with nothing but a chair?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: This answer satisfies me a hundred percent.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: We all have abnormality in common. We are a breed apart from the rest of the humanity, we Theater folk. We are the original displaced personalities...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: In my case it's necessary. Too many taxi drivers write plays.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: And too many of them are produced.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I'm giving her a very high-class party. It ain't like a rehearsal, she don't have to be late.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: As soon as the peasants stop pawing her.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Then stop being a star - start treating your guests as your supporting cast!

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Hear, hear...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: She was magnificent.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Then you've heard too.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I was there. An eyewitness.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You were there? At the play - last night?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: A happy coincidence.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: From the smartness of your dress, I take it your luncheon companion is a lady?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Margo.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Margo? Lunching in public?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: It's new Margo. But she's just as late as the old one.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: She may be later than you think...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I distinctly remember striking your name from the guest list. What are you doing here?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Dear Margo. You were an unforgettable Peter Pan - you must play it again, soon. You remember Miss Caswell?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I do not. How do you do?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Eve, this is an old friend of Mr. deWitt's mother - Miss Caswell, Miss Harrington...  Addison, I've been wanting you to meet Eve for the longest time-

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: It could only have been your natural timidity that kept you from mentioning it...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You've heard of her great interest in the Theater-

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: We have that in common.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Then you two must have a long talk-

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: You mustn't worry about your little charge. She is in safe hands.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Amen.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Why so remote, Addison? I should think you'd be at the side of your protegee, lending her moral support...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Miss Caswell, at the moment, is where I can lend no support - moral or otherwise.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The ladies' - shall we say - lounge?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Being violently ill to her tummy.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It's good luck before an audition. She'll be all right once it starts.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Miss Caswell got lucky too late. The audition is over.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Over? It can't be. I've come to read with her. I promised Max.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: The audition was called for 2:30. It is now nearly four.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Is it really? I must start wearing a watch, I never do, you know... who read with Miss Caswell? Bill?  Lloyd?  Well, it couldn't have been Max! Who?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Naturally enough, your understudy.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I consider it highly unnatural to allow a girl in an advanced state of pregnancy-

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: I refer to your new and unpregnant understudy. Eve Harrington.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Eve! My understudy...

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Didn't you know?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Of course I knew.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: It just slipped your mind.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How... how was Miss Caswell?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Frankly, I don't remember.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Just slipped your mind.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Completely. Nor, I am sure, could anyone else present tell you how Miss Caswell read or whether Miss Caswell read or rode a pogo stick.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Was she that bad?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Margo, as you know, i have lived in the Theater as a Trappist monk lives in his faith. I have no other world, no other life - and once in a great while I experience that moment of Revelation for which all true believers wait and pray. You were one. Jeanne Eagels another... Paula Wessely... Hayes - there are others, three or four. Eve Harrington will be among them...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I take it she read well.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: It wasn't reading, it was a performance. Brilliant, vivid, something made of music and fire...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How nice.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: In time she'll be what you are.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: A mass of music and fire. That's me. An old kazoo and some sparkles. Tell me - was Bill swept away, too, or were you too full of Revelation to notice?

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Bill didn't say - but Lloyd was beside himself. He listened to his play as if someone else had written it, he said, it sounded so fresh, so new, so full of meaning...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How nice for Lloyd. And how nice for Eve. How nice for everybody.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: Eve was incredibly modest. She insisted that no credit was due her, that Lloyd felt as he did only because she read lines exactly as he had written them.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The implication being that I have not been reading them as written.

turns.speaker: ADDISON
turns.text: To the best of my recollection, neither your name nor your performance entered the conversation.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Bill...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The air lines have clocks, even if you haven't! I start shooting a week from Monday - Zanuck is impatient, he wants me, he needs me!

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Bill-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Bill!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: This is Eve Harrington.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You've already met.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Right here. A minute ago.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: That's nice.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Good luck, genius...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Geniuses don't need good luck.  I do.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Macbeth.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: We know you, we've seen you before like this. Is it over - or just beginning?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I guess at this point I'm what the French call 'de trop'...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Maybe just a little around the edges.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: When? When are you going to do it?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Tomorrow we meet at City Hall at ten-  - and you're going to be on time.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Nothing?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Everything... everything's so funny...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Forty-five minutes from now my plane takes off and how do I find you? Not ready yet, looking like a junk yard-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Thank you so much.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Is it sabotage, does my career mean nothing to you? Have you no human consideration?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Show me a human and I might have!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Only in some ways. You're prettier...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm a junk yard.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Hi.  My wonderful junk yard. The mystery and dreams you find in a junk yard-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Heaven help me, I love a psychotic.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Oh well...  ... look through the wigs, maybe it got caught-

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Real diamonds in a wig. The world we live in...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Where's my coat?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Can't keep his eyes off my legs.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Like a nylon lemon peel-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Byron couldn't have said it more graciously... here we go-

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: She's quite a girl, that what's-her name...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Eve. I'd forgotten they grew that way...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The lack of pretense, that sort of strange directness and understanding-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Did she tell you about the Theater and what it meant?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I told her. I sounded off.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: All the religions in the world rolled into one, and we're Gods and Goddesses... isn't it silly, suddenly I've developed a big protective feeling for her - a lamb loose in our big stone jungle...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Take care of yourself out there...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I understand they've got the Indians pretty well in hand...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Bill...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Don't get stuck on some glamour puss-

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'll try.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You're not such a bargain, you know, conceited and thoughtless and messy-

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Everybody can't be Gregory Peck.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: - you're a setup for some gorgeous wide-eyed young babe.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: How childish are you going to get before you quit it?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I don't want to be childish, I'd settle for just a few years-

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: And cut that out right now.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Am I going to lose you, Bill? Am I?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: As of this moment you're six years old...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Knit me a muffler.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Call me when you get in...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What a thoughtful, ever-lovin' thing to do-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Bill? Have I gone crazy, Bill?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You're my girl, aren't you?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That I am...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Then you're crazy.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: When - when are you coming back?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I leave in a week - the picture's all wrapped up, we previewed last night... those previews. Like opening out of town, but terrifying. There's nothing you can do, you're trapped, you're in a tin can-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: - in a tin can, cellophane or wrapped in a Navajo blanket, I want you home...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You in a hurry?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: A big hurry, be quick about it - so good night, darling, and sleep tight...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Wait a minute! You can't hang up, you haven't even said it-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Bill, you know how much I do - but over the phone, now really, that's kid stuff...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Kid stuff or not, it doesn't happen every day, I want to heat it - and if you won't say it, you can sing it...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Sing it?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Sure! Like the Western Union boys used to do...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Bill... Bill, it's your birthday.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: And who remembered it? Who was there on the dot, at twelve midnight...?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Happy birthday, darling...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The reading could have been better, but you said it - now "many happy returns of the day..."

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Many happy returns of the day...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I get a party, don't I?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Of course, birthday and welcome home... who'll I ask?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's no secret, I know all about the party - Eve wrote me...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She did...?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: She hasn't missed a week since I left - but you know all that, you probably tell her what to write... anyway, I sent her a list of people to ask - check with her.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Yeah... I will.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: How is Eve? Okay?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I love you...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'll check with Eve...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I love you too. Good night, darling-

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: See you...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Outside of a beehive, Margo, your behavior would hardly be considered either queenly or motherly!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You're in a beehive, pal, didn't you know? We're all busy little bees, full of stings, making honey day and night-  - aren't we, honey?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's a good thought.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It won't play.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Happy little housewife...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Cut it out.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: This is my house, not a theater! In my house you're a guest, not a director-!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Need any help?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: To put me to bed? Take my clothes off, hold my head, tuck me in, turn off the lights, tiptoe out...? eve would. Wouldn't you, Eve?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Don't let me kill the point. Or isn't it a story for grownups?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You've heard it. About when I looked through the wrong end of a camera finder.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Remind me to tell you about when I looked into the heart of an artichoke.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Looks like I'm going to have a very fancy party...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I thought you were going to be late-

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: When I'm guest of honor?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I had no idea you were even here.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I ran into Eve on my way upstairs; she told me you were dressing.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That never stopped you before.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Well, we started talking, she wanted to know all about Hollywood, she seemed so interested...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She's a girl of so many interests.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's a pretty rare quality these days.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She's a girl of so many rare qualities.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: So she seems.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: So you've pointed out, so often. So many qualities, so often. Her loyalty, efficiency, devotion, warmth, affection - and so young. So young and so fair...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I can't believe you're making this up - it sounds like something out of an old Clyde Fitch play...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Clyde Fitch, thought you may not think so, was well before my time!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I've always denied the legend that you were in 'Our American Cousin' the night Lincoln was shot...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I don't think that's funny!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Of course it's funny - this is all too laughable to be anything else. You know what I think about this - this age obsession of yours - and now this ridiculous attempt to whip yourself up into a jealous froth because I spent ten minutes with a stage-struck kid-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Twenty minutes!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Thirty minutes, forty minutes! What of it?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Stage-struck kid... she's a young lady - of qualities. And I'll have you know I'm fed up with both the young lady and her qualities! Studying me as if - as if I were a play or a set of blueprints! How I walk, talk, think, eat, sleep!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Now how can you take offense at a kid trying in every way to be as much like her ideal as possible!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Stop calling her a kid! It so happens there are particular aspects of my life to which I would like to maintain sole and exclusive rights and privileges!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: For instance what?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: For instance - you!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: This is my cue to take you in my arms and reassure you - but I'm not going to. I'm too mad-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: - guilty.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Mad! Darling, there are certain characteristics for which you are famous - on stage and off. I love you for some of them - and in spite of others. I haven't let those become too important to me. They're part of your equipment for getting along in what is laughably called out environment - you've got to keep your teeth sharp. All right. But you will not sharpen them on me - or on Eve...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What about her teeth? What about her fangs?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: She hasn't cut them yet, and you know it! So when you start judging an idealistic dreamy-eyed kid by the barroom, Benzedrine standards of this megalomaniac society - I won't have it! Eve Harrington has never by word, look, thought or suggestion indicated anything to me but her adoration for you and her happiness at our being in love! And to intimate anything else doesn't spell jealousy to me - it spells a paranoic insecurity that you should be ashamed of!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Cut! Print it! What happens in the next reel? Do I get dragged off screaming to the snake pit?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Nothing, really...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The kid - junior, that is - will be right down. Unless you'd like to take her drink up to her...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I can always get a fresh one. Karen - you're a Gibson girl...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Many of your guests have been wondering when they may be permitted to view the body. Where has it been laid out?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It hasn't been laid out, we haven't finished with the embalming. As a matter of fact, you're looking at it. The remains of Margo Channing. Sitting up. It is my last wish to be buried sitting up.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Wouldn't you feel more natural taking a bow?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You know nothing about feelings, natural or unnatural.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Then without feeling, your guests were also wondering whether the music couldn't be a shade more on the - shall we say, happier side?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: If my guests do not like it here, I suggest they accompany you to the nursery where I'm sure you will all feel more at home.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: No heart to burn.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Everybody has a heart - except some people.  Of course I've got bicarb. There's a box in the pantry. We'll put your name on it. Max Fabian. It'll say there. Always. Just for you.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's all over.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What's all over?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The audition.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Eve?  How enchanting...  Wherever did you get the idea of having Eve read with Miss Caswell?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What fire and music?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You wouldn't understand.  How was Miss Caswell?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Addison-!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: So full of meaning, fire and music!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: And you, I take it, are the Paderewski who plays his concerto on me, the piano?  Where is Princess Fire-and-Music?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The kid. Junior.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Gone.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I must have frightened her away.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I wouldn't be surprised. Sometimes you frighten me.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Poor little flower. Just dropped her petals and folded her tent...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Don't mix your metaphors.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I mix what I like.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Okay. Mix.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm nothing but a body with a voice. No mind.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What a body, what a voice.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The ex-ship news' reporter. No body, no voice, all mind!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The gong rang. The fight's over. Calm down.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I will not calm down!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Don't calm down.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You're being terribly tolerant, aren't you?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'm trying terribly hard.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Well, you needn't. I will not be tolerated. And I will not be plotted against!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Here we go...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Such nonsense, what do you all take me for - little Nell from the country? Been my understudy for over a week without my knowing, carefully hidden no doubt-

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Now don't get carried away-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: - shows up for an audition when everyone knew I'd be here... and gives a performance! Out of nowhere - gives a performance!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You've been all through that with Lloyd-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The playwright doesn't make the performance - and it doesn't just happen! And this one didn't - full of fire and music and whatnot, it was carefully rehearsed I have no doubt, over and over, full of those Bill Sampson touches!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I am sick and tired of these paranoiac outbursts!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Paranoiac!

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I didn't know Eve Harrington was your understudy until half past two this afternoon!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Tell that to Dr. Freud! Along with the rest of it...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: No, I'll tell it to you! For the last time, I'll tell it to you. Because you've got to stop hurting yourself, and me, and the two of us by these paranoiac tantrums!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That word again! I don't even know what it means...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's time you found out. I love you.  I love you. You're a beautiful and intelligent woman-  - a beautiful and intelligent woman and a great actress-  - at the peak of her career. You have every reason for happiness-  - every reason, but due to some strange, uncontrollable, unconscious drive you permit the slightest action of a kid-  - kid like Eve to turn you into a hysterical, screaming harpy! Now once and for all, stop it!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It's obvious you're not a woman.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I've been aware of that for some time.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Well, I am.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I'll say.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Don't be condescending.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Come on, get up. I'll buy you a drink.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I admit I may have seen better days, but I am still not to be had for the price of a cocktail - like a salted peanut.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Margo, let's make peace.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The terms are too high. Unconditional surrender.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Just being happy? Just stopping all this nonsense about Eve - and Eve and me?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It's not nonsense.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: But if I tell you it is - as I just did. Were you listening to me?  Isn't that enough?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I wish it were.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Then what would be enough?  If we were married?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I wouldn't want you to marry me just to prove something.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You've had so many reasons for not wanting to marry me... Margo, tell me what's behind all this.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I - I don't know, Bill. Just a feeling, I don't know...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I think you do know but you won't or can't tell me.  I said before it was going to be my last try, and I meant it. I can't think of anything else to do. I wish I could.  We usually wind up screaming and throwing things as the curtain comes down. Then it comes up again and everything's fine. But not this time.  You know there isn't a playwright in the world who could make me believe this would happen between two adult people. Goodbye, Margo.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Bill...  ... where are you going? To find Eve?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: That suddenly makes the whole thing believable.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The so-called art of acting is not one for which I have a particularly high regard...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Hear, hear...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: But you may quote me as follows. Quote. Tonight Miss Margo Channing gave a performance in your cockamamie play, the like of which I have never seen before and expect rarely to see again. Unquote.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: He does not exaggerate. I was good.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You were great.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: To Margo. To my bride-to-be.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Glory Hallelujah.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: It's only for the license. There's a three-day wait - blood tests, things like that...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'll marry you if it turns out you have no blood at all.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Something simple. A fur coat over a nightgown...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: The point is - in the cathedral, a ball park or a penny arcade - we want to have you two beside us our nearest and dearest friends.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: "Please forgive me for butting into what seems such a happy occasion - but it's most important that I speak with you. Please" - it's underlined - "meet me in the Ladies' Room. Eve."

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: I understand she is now the understudy in there.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Pass me the empty bottle. I may find her... why, look. There's Rasputin.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Groom-  - may I have a wedding present?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: What would you like? Texas?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I want everybody to shut up about Eve. Just shut up about Eve, that's all I want. Give Karen more wine...  ... never have I been so happy. Isn't this a lovely room? The Cub Room. What a lovely, clever name. Where the elite meet. Never have I seen so much elite - and all with their eyes on me. Waiting for me to crack that little gnome over the noggin with a bottle. But not tonight. Even Eve. I forgive Eve... there they go.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: There goes Eve. Eve evil, Little Miss Evil. But the evil that men do - how does it go, groom? Something about the good they leave behind - I played it once in rep in Wilkes Barre...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: You've got it backwards. Even for Wilkes-Barre.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You know why I forgive Eve? Because she's left good behind - the four of us, together like this, it's Eve's fault - I forgive her...

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Never try to outguess Margo.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Groom.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Yes, dear.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You know what I'm going to be?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: A cowboy.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: A married lady.

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: With the paper to prove it.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm going to have a home. Not just a house I'm afraid to stay in... and a man to go with it. I'll look up at six o'clock - and there he'll be... remember, Karen?

turns.speaker: BILL
turns.text: Often enough to keep the franchise.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: A foursquare, upright, downright, forthright married lady... that's for me. And no more make believe! Off stage or on... remember, Lloyd.  I mean it, now. Grown-up women only, I might even play a mother - only one child, of course, not over eight...  Lloyd, will you promise not to be angry with me?
